SENT.plain: An 84-year-old man presented with the chief complaints of fever and disturbance of consciousness at another hospital
A sheath dilator had been inserted into the urethra instead of an indwelling catheter at the hospital
Since he had previously been treated for myelodysplastic syndrome in our Department of Internal Medicine, he was transferred to our hospital
He presented at our Department with the chief complaints of urinary difficulty and lower abdominal fullness
Kidney-ureter-bladder x-ray and computed tomography revealed the sheath dilator in the uretha and bladder
First, we performed a percutaneous cystostomy under local anesthesia
Second, we utilized optical forceps and successfully removed the sheath dilator transurethrally under intravenous anesthesia
